citations.title: History of Space Travel | National Geographic Kids

lines.quote: Learn about the history of humans traveling into space.

citations.title: Space exploration - Milestones, Achievements, History | Britannica

lines.quote: Since ancient times, people around the world have studied the heavens and used their observations and explanations of astronomical phenomena for both religious and practical purposes. Some dreamed of leaving Earth to explore other worlds. For example, the French satirist [Cyrano de Bergerac](https://www.britannica.com/biography/Savinien-Cyrano-de-Bergerac) in the 17th century wrote *Histoire comique des états et empires de la lune* (1656) and *Histoire comique des états et empires du soleil* (1662; together in English as *A Voyage to the Moon: With Some Account of the Solar World*, 1754), describing fictional journeys to the [Moon](https://www.britannica.com/science/moon-natural-satellite) and the [Sun](https://www.britannica.com/place/Sun). Two centuries later the French author [Jules Verne](https://www.britannica.com/biography/Jules-Verne) and the English novelist and historian [H.G. Wells](https://www.britannica.com/biography/H-G-Wells) infused their stories with descriptions of [outer space](https://www.britannica.com/science/outer-space) and of spaceflight that were consistent with the best understanding of the time. Verne’s [ De la Terre à la Lune](https://www.britannica.com/topic/From-the-Earth-to-the-Moon-novel-by-Verne) (1865;

In the [United States](https://www.britannica.com/place/United-States), [Robert Hutchings Goddard](https://www.britannica.com/biography/Robert-Goddard) became interested in space exploration after reading works such as * The War of the Worlds*. Even as a young man, he dedicated himself to working on spaceflight. In his 1904 high-school graduation speech, he stated that “it is difficult to say what is impossible, for the dream of yesterday is the hope of today and the reality of tomorrow.” Goddard received his first two patents for

[A Method of Reaching Extreme Altitudes](https://www.britannica.com/topic/A-Method-of-Reaching-Extreme-Altitudes)[Moon](https://www.britannica.com/place/Moon)was widely ridiculed in the public press, including
A list of significant [milestones](https://www.britannica.com/dictionary/milestones) in space exploration is provided in the table.

citations.title: A Brief History of Space Exploration | The Aerospace Corporation

lines.quote: In April 1981, the launch of the space shuttle Columbia ushered in a period of reliance on the reusable shuttle for most civilian and military space missions. Twenty-four successful shuttle launches fulfilled many scientific and military requirements until Jan. 28,1986, when just 73 seconds after liftoff, the space shuttle Challenger exploded. The crew of seven was killed, including Christa McAuliffe, a teacher from New Hampshire who would have been the first civilian in space.

The International Space Station is a research laboratory in low Earth orbit. With many different partners contributing to its design and construction, this high-flying laboratory has become a symbol of cooperation in space exploration, with former competitors now working together.

During the 1960s, unmanned spacecraft photographed and probed the Moon before astronauts ever landed. By the early 1970s, orbiting communications and navigation satellites were in everyday use, and the Mariner spacecraft was orbiting and mapping the surface of Mars. By the end of the decade, the Voyager spacecraft had sent back detailed images of Jupiter and Saturn, their rings, and their moons.

Skylab, America’s first space station, was a human-spaceflight highlight of the 1970s, as was the Apollo Soyuz Test Project, the world’s first internationally crewed (American and Russian) space mission.
